title: Has the percentage of women who are smokers at the time of delivery decreased?
analysis_commentary:
The percentage of women who are known to be smokers at the time of delivery has been decreasing over time. In 2006/07, 15.8% of pregnant women were smokers and this decreased to 10.7% in 2016/17. Despite this 5% decrease in prevalence, the reduction in smoking rates among pregnant women has slowed in the past year with a percentage decrease of only 0.3%; this prompted concern from health charities. The previous target to reduce the percentage of women who smoke during pregnancy to 11% or less was met in 2015/16, and in July 2017 a new target was set to reduce the prevalence to 6% or less by 2022. This is part of the Department of Health's Towards a Smokefree Generation tobacco control plan for England.

Updated December 2017.
data_source: NHS Digital, Statistics on Women's Smoking Status at Time of Delivery
